Fed to Cut Banking Supervision Staff by 30%
AbbVie raises its annual forecast despite sluggish quarterly earnings
data.description:
AbbVie has reported Q3 2025 adjusted net income of $3.31bn, down 38% year-on-year. Adjusted EPS reached $1.86, compared to $3.00 a year earlier.

On a reported basis, net income was $186m, a fraction - down 88.1% - from the $1.56bn a year earlier.

Quarterly revenue was $15.776bn (slightly below consensus expectations), up 9.1% as reported and up 8.4% at constant exchange rates.
In detail, the immunology portfolio grew 11.9% to $7.885bn, the neuroscience segment grew 20.2% to $2.841bn, oncology sales remained stable at $1.682bn, and aesthetics declined 3.7% to $1.193bn.

AbbVie continues to deliver strong results, with significant momentum across key segments of our portfolio. We are also making progress in our pipeline and investments in innovation, it said.

Based on this performance, the group is raising its adjusted EPS forecast for FY 2025, now expected to be between $10.61 and $10.65, up from $10.38 to $10.58 previously. This guidance includes an unfavorable impact of $2.05 per share related to acquired IPR&D expenses and milestones already incurred in the first nine months of the year.

Following this announcement, the stock fell 3% in pre-market trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

Ramaco Shares Up on Critical-Minerals Stockpile Collaboration With Goldman Sachs
data.description:
By Adriano Marchese


Ramaco Resources shares rose after the miner announced a collaboration with Goldman Sachs to develop a specialized critical-materials and rare-earth minerals terminal at its site in Wyoming.

Shares traded 15% higher at $34.08 in early trading.

Ramaco said on Friday that Goldman Sachs will act as the exclusive structuring agent for its plan to establish a strategic critical-minerals terminal at its Brook Mine facility.

The terminal will serve as a centralized facility for storing and managing critical minerals and rare-earth elements, with potential tolling and processing services for third-party producers, the Lexington, Ky., company said.

The initiative aims to support domestic supply chain stability and national security by offering long-term inventory solutions, said Ramaco.


Write to Adriano Marchese at adriano.marchese@wsj.com


(END) Dow Jones Newswires

10-31-25 0950ET

Dallas Fed's Logan : Central Bank Was Wrong to Cut This Rates Week
data.description:
By Matt Grossman


Dallas Fed President Lorie Logan pushed back on the Federal Reserve's quarter-point interest-rate cut this week, arguing that the risk of a slowing job market didn't justify swerving away from the task of corralling inflation.

Speaking at a conference in Dallas Friday morning, Logan observed that weaker job creation hasn't led to a drastic rise in the unemployment rate, partly because the pool of people looking for work has ebbed. Meanwhile, she said, she isn't convinced inflation is on a firm track back toward the Fed's 2% target.

That combination suggests the Fed should be more reluctant to cut rates to support the labor market with rate cuts, which weaken the Fed's anti-inflation stance, Logan said.

Logan hasn't been a member of the Fed's policy committee this year, under the system that rotates votes annually among the Fed's 12 reserve-bank presidents. But she made it clear that if she had gotten a vote this week, she would have dissented against the Fed's cut.

"I would have preferred to hold interest rates steady," Logan said, according to a published version of her remarks. She said later in the speech that she is also skeptical that a further cut in December will be the right move.

The Fed's decision to cut rates by a quarter point to a range of 3.75% to 4% at a second straight meeting was contentious, with two voters dissenting. Kansas City Fed President Jeffrey Schmid took the same view as Logan, arguing the Fed should have kept rates still. Fed governor Stephen Miran dissented in the other direction, backing a half-point rate cut.

In a press conference after the vote, Chair Jerome Powell said that another cut in December--something that many traders had been counting on--was far from a foregone conclusion. His comments likely reflected a base of skepticism about further cuts among the Fed's policy committee as the group met over two days this week.

Logan acknowledged that the labor market has weakened, but said that future policy choices could respond quickly if the situation worsens further. "These are all risks the FOMC will be able to closely monitor and address promptly if there is evidence they are becoming more likely to materialize," she said, referring to the Fed's policy committee by its acronym.

On the other hand, she expressed impatience with persistent inflation, noting that prices already rose nearly at the Fed's annual target rate between January and August alone. Inflation is " still not convincingly headed all the way back to 2 percent," she said. She added that the Fed's 2% inflation target is a "serious commitment."


Write to Matt Grossman at matt.grossman@wsj.com


(END) Dow Jones Newswires

10-31-25 0944ET

AbbVie boosts profit view on resilient demand for newer immunology drugs
data.description:
(Reuters) -AbbVie raised its 2025 profit forecast on Friday, after strong sales of newer immunology drugs Skyrizi and Rinvoq helped boost third-quarter results above estimates.

The North Chicago-based drugmaker has been leaning on Skyrizi and Rinvoq to offset declining sales of its once best-selling arthritis treatment Humira that began facing biosimilar competition in the U.S. in 2023.

However, shares of the company were down nearly 4% in early trading, after sales from its aesthetics products portfolio - home to popular anti-wrinkle treatment Botox - fell 3.7% from last year.

"Another weaker quarter for the Aesthetics business could raise some eyebrows ... continued headwinds mount across products, including Botox and fillers," said BMO Capital Markets analyst Evan Seigerman.

Concerns about the economy and inflation are weighing on customer spending, pulling growth in the category below the company's previous assumptions globally, said Jeffrey Stewart, AbbVie's chief commercial officer, on a call with analysts.

AbbVie now expects adjusted annual profit per share of between $10.61 and $10.65, compared with its previous expectations of $10.38 to $10.58.

Its quarterly sales of $15.78 billion beat analysts' average estimate of $15.59 billion, according to data compiled by LSEG.

Global sales of AbbVie's flagship arthritis treatment Humira came in at $993 million in the third quarter, missing estimates of $1.15 billion, and marking the first time the drug's sales have dropped below $1 billion since it lost exclusivity.

During the quarter, Skyrizi brought in sales of $4.71 billion, surpassing estimates of $4.44 billion, while Rinvoq sales of $2.18 billion topped estimates of $2.12 billion.

"The delta between actuals and consensus are narrower than previous quarters, but both drugs managed to pull it out of the bag," Bernstein analyst Courtney Breen said.

The drugmaker earned quarterly profit per share of $1.86, above estimates of $1.77 per share.

(Reporting by Siddhi Mahatole and Puyaan Singh in Bengaluru; Editing by Devika Syamnath)

Danske Bank A/S Reports Earnings Results for the Third Quarter and Nine Months Ended September 30, 2025
data.description:
Danske Bank A/S reported earnings results for the third quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2025. For the third quarter, the company reported net income was DKK 5,520 million compared to DKK 6,165 million a year ago. Basic earnings per share from continuing operations was DKK 6.7 compared to DKK 7.2 a year ago. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was DKK 6.7 compared to DKK 7.2 a year ago.
For the nine months, net income was DKK 16,730 million compared to DKK 17,634 million a year ago. Basic earnings per share from continuing operations was DKK 20.2 compared to DKK 20.7 a year ago. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was DKK 20.2 compared to DKK 20.7 a year ago.

data.title: Tokyo Electron Limited Revises Dividend Guidance for the First Half of Fiscal Year Ending March 31, 2026, Payable on November 28, 2025
data.description:
Tokyo Electron Limited announced that on October 31, 2025, its Board of Directors had passed a resolution to pay interim dividend from surplus (for the first half of the fiscal year ending March 31, 2026) to shareholders of record as of September 30, 2025. The dividends for the first half ended September 30, 2025 were revised upward to JPY 264 per share from previously announced JPY 245 per share. The effective date is November 28, 2025.

Reason: The dividend policy of TEL is to link dividend payments to business performance on an ongoing basis. Its basic policy for returning profits to shareholders is to maintain a payout ratio of around 50% based on net income attributable to owners of parent. The consolidated results for the first half of the current fiscal year showed an increase compared to the previous forecast announced on July 31, 2025.

Cenovus Energy Inc. Reports Earnings Results for the Third Quarter and Nine Months Ended September 30, 2025
data.description:
Cenovus Energy Inc. reported earnings results for the third quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2025. For the third quarter, the company reported sales was CAD 13,195 million compared to CAD 13,819 million a year ago. Net income was CAD 1,286 million compared to CAD 820 million a year ago. Basic earnings per share from continuing operations was CAD 0.72 compared to CAD 0.44 a year ago. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was CAD 0.72 compared to CAD 0.42 a year ago.
For the nine months, sales was CAD 38,813 million compared to CAD 41,464 million a year ago. Net income was CAD 2,996 million compared to CAD 2,996 million a year ago. Basic earnings per share from continuing operations was CAD 1.65 compared to CAD 1.6 a year ago. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was CAD 1.65 compared to CAD 1.59 a year ago.

Aon plc Reports Earnings Results for the Third Quarter and Nine Months Ended September 30, 2025
data.description:
Aon plc reported earnings results for the third quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2025. For the third quarter, the company reported sales was USD 3,997 million compared to USD 3,721 million a year ago. Net income was USD 458 million compared to USD 343 million a year ago. Basic earnings per share from continuing operations was USD 2.12 compared to USD 1.58 a year ago. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was USD 2.11 compared to USD 1.57 a year ago.
For the nine months, sales was USD 12,881 million compared to USD 11,551 million a year ago. Net income was USD 2,002 million compared to USD 1,938 million a year ago. Basic earnings per share from continuing operations was USD 9.26 compared to USD 9.24 a year ago. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was USD 9.21 compared to USD 9.2 a year ago.

data.title: Church & Dwight Co., Inc. Reports Earnings Results for the Third Quarter and Nine Months Ended September 30, 2025
data.description:
Church & Dwight Co., Inc. reported earnings results for the third quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2025. For the third quarter, the company reported sales was USD 1,585.6 million compared to USD 1,510.6 million a year ago. Net income was USD 182.2 million compared to net loss of USD 75.1 million a year ago. Basic earnings per share from continuing operations was USD 0.75 compared to basic loss per share from continuing operations of USD 0.31 a year ago. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was USD 0.75 compared to diluted loss per share from continuing operations of USD 0.31 a year ago.
For the nine months, sales was USD 4,559 million compared to USD 4,525.1 million a year ago. Net income was USD 593.3 million compared to USD 396.1 million a year ago. Basic earnings per share from continuing operations was USD 2.43 compared to USD 1.62 a year ago. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was USD 2.41 compared to USD 1.61 a year ago.

Colgate-Palmolive Company Reports Earnings Results for the Third Quarter and Nine Months Ended September 30, 2025
data.description:
Colgate-Palmolive Company reported earnings results for the third quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2025. For the third quarter, the company reported sales was USD 5,131 million compared to USD 5,033 million a year ago. Net income was USD 735 million compared to USD 737 million a year ago. Basic earnings per share from continuing operations was USD 0.91 compared to USD 0.9 a year ago. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was USD 0.91 compared to USD 0.9 a year ago.
For the nine months, sales was USD 15,152 million compared to USD 15,156 million a year ago. Net income was USD 2,169 million compared to USD 2,150 million a year ago. Basic earnings per share from continuing operations was USD 2.68 compared to USD 2.62 a year ago. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was USD 2.67 compared to USD 2.61 a year ago.

data.title: Charter Communications, Inc. Reports Earnings Results for the Third Quarter and Nine Months Ended September 30, 2025
data.description:
Charter Communications, Inc. reported earnings results for the third quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2025. For the third quarter, the company reported sales was USD 13,672 million compared to USD 13,795 million a year ago. Net income was USD 1,137 million compared to USD 1,280 million a year ago. Basic earnings per share from continuing operations was USD 8.5 compared to USD 8.99 a year ago. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was USD 8.34 compared to USD 8.82 a year ago.
For the nine months, sales was USD 41,173 million compared to USD 41,159 million a year ago. Net income was USD 3,655 million compared to USD 3,617 million a year ago. Basic earnings per share from continuing operations was USD 26.52 compared to USD 25.23 a year ago. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was USD 25.95 compared to USD 24.86 a year ago.
